item.title: Learn linear-gradient() by designing a complex chess pattern
item.description: Imma show you how to create smooth patterns and stripes to add a touch of professionalism to your design. Then we will design a chess board using CSS3.
item.dc:creator: NedalKouissi
item.content:encoded:
You can read and watch previous episodes here!

Introduction

This is what you'll design by the end of this tutorial

You'll be able to do it with the help of linear-gradient() and on top of that, Imma show you how to create smooth patterns and stripes to add a touch of professionalism to your design.

1. What's the basic usage?

This is the syntax of linear-gradient(). I took it from MDN.

background: linear-gradient([ [ [ <angle> | to [top | bottom] || [left | right] ],]? <color-stop>[, <color-stop>]+);

What the hell is that?

Most of your future time will be spent on documentation, so I should probably make it easy for you.

  • brackets[] to make a group.

  • anything followed by ?, means it's not required and it could be skipped.

  • | that's OR. I'm just saying don't get mad.

in our example we have [left | right] which means we can add the keyword left or right to linear-gradient() also we can omit them.

  • Whenever you see + know that you can have as many as you want of that property value.

Back to our example, we have [, <color-stop>]+ it means we can add as much colors-stop as we want.

Still confused? No worries, imma show you how I did the first part step by step

[ [ [ <angle> | to [top | bottom] || [left | right] ],]?

First, I looked out for the first comma , everything before it, is just one value property.

[ Value property ,]?

and that value property isn't required, becuase it's wrapped inside []? so we can omit it if we want to.

all we have now is
value property

in other words

[ <angle> | to [top | bottom] || [left | right] ]

The first option here is the angle, something like 45deg or 90deg.
The second option is the keyword to followed by top or bottom and what's interesting is top or bottom could also be followed by left or right. You can tell it by ||.

Okay here's some combination I could make.

background: linear-gradient(45deg);  
background: linear-gradient(to top);  
background: linear-gradient(to bottom left);  
background: linear-gradient(to bottom right);  
background: linear-gradient(to left);

Now you have abilities to read the second part <color-stop>[, <color-stop>]+.

Open your text editor and follow, I'll start with div

<div class="box"></div>

in css imma add

.box {
  width: 50%;
  height: 6em;
  background: red;
}

we'll have something like this

liner-gradient is a function that goes with background or background-image. Let's remove that red color and replace it with this

background: linear-gradient(to right, black, white);

the results are

I could also have written the last line as follow 

background: linear-gradient(90deg, black, white);

Wait, when should I use deg instead of keywords?

This is what keywords can do 

to top  
to top left  
to top right

to bottom  
to bottom left  
to bottom right

to left  
to right

As you see they are limited, so if you need more control or you feel lazy to type, go with deg.

Things get interesting when we add percentages to any color stop

background: linear-gradient(90deg, black 10%, red);

Now it's time to understand how color stop work.

Setting both black and red at 50%

background: linear-gradient(90deg, black 50%, red 50%);

there is no fade in or fade out, between these two colors.

let's change black to 40%. I added a blue separator to help you understand what's going on

background: linear-gradient(90deg, black 40%, red 50%);

black is painted from 0% to 40%
red is painted from 50% to 100%

The blue separator is 40% from the left, Red color started at 50%, the fade happened in between that 40% 50% space.
You get it ?

something else you need to know, this line

background: linear-gradient(90deg, black 40%, red 50%);

is equally the same as this line

background:  
  linear-gradient(
    90deg, 
    black 0%, black 40%,
    red 50%, red 100%
  );

Now the picture must be clear, But It gets complicated when we start adding more than two colors, for that reason imma show you how to deal with it.

You still remember when we did 50% black, 50% red

Because we have two different colors at the same position, the transition between these two is none rather than smooth.

Now I need to show you how to create the same effect in a different way, it'll come in handy when we start using multiple colors

background: linear-gradient(90deg, black 50%, red 0);

We set the second color's position at 0, the browser will automatically adjust its position to be equal to the previous color stop, which is 50%.

When I use multiple colors stop, I always start simple something like below

background: linear-gradient(90deg,  
  #BFBDC1 20%,
  #6D6A75 0, #6D6A75 40%,
  #1E1C22 0, #1E1C22 60%,
  #DEB841 0, #DEB841 80%,
  #DE9E36 0, #DE9E36
  );

color1 ends at 20%
color 2 starts at 20%
color3 starts at 40%
color4 starts at 60%
color5 starts at 80%

Then I change the smoothness between colors to my taste

background: linear-gradient(90deg,  
  #BFBDC1 10%,
  #6D6A75 30%,
  #1E1C22 40%,
  #DEB841 80%,
  #DE9E36
  );

I've removed all hard colors stop colorX 0,, they were there as guides no more :)

now we have something like this

It's much easier to lay down your colors then fade them till you get the end result.

You can create beautiful fades with this technique

background: linear-gradient(90deg,  
  #EAEAEA 4%,
  #C1C1C2 30%,
  #98979A 40%,
  #6F6E72 80%,
  #323036
  );

2. How to create patterns using linear-background?

Let's create something that we may often encounter in our daily basis.
Tiny patterns to spice any background you want, in our example we'll work on body {}. 

background:  
  repeating-linear-gradient(90deg, 
    #EAEAEA 0, #EAEAEA 20%,
    white 0, #EAEAEA 40%,
    white 0, #EAEAEA 60%
  );

Wait, REPEATING? What's that?

It works exactly like linear-background, but It repeats the pattern automatically.

So this is what I have

By now, you're more than able to do the same. Let's see what will happen if we make that pattern so small via background-size.

background-size: 0.2em 1em;

the end result is

Beautiful right ?

3. Take it to the next level

Wouldn't be nice if we spice it a bit with some randomness? So the user wouldn't be able to notice the repitive pattern.

I'ma choose some bright colors to make it easy for you to follow.

repeating-linear-gradient(90deg,  
    black 0, black 20%,
    red 0, red 40%,
    white 0, #EAEAEA 60%
  );

This is what we have

We need to go back to linear-gradient instead of repeating-linear-gradient, because we gonna layer them so we could add randomness to make it look less repetitive.

linear-gradient(90deg,  
    black 0, black 20%,
    red 0, red 40%,
    white 0, #EAEAEA 60%
);

The pattern ain't repetitive anymore, we need to create that repetition manually

background:  
  linear-gradient(90deg, 
    black 0, black 20%,
    red 0, red 40%,
    white 0, #EAEAEA 60%,
    red 0, red 80%,
    black 0, black
);

results are now similar to our previous repeating-linear-gradient

When we type black 20%, red 0, we're saying that we want 20% of space to be black then after that we will have a new color stop which will be red.
ignore red for now and act like you don't know what the next color could be.

I can write the previous line as

background: linear-gradient(90deg, black 20%, transparent 0);

guess what? Now I can layer the second red color stop like the following

background:  
  linear-gradient(90deg, black 20%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, red 40%, transparent 0);

And after layering all the remaining layers here's the final result

background:  
  linear-gradient(90deg, black 20%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, red 40%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, #EAEAEA 60%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, red 80%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, black 100%, transparent 0);

Back to background-size we can achieve some crazy randomness by controlling each color stop space

background-size:  
  2em 100%,
  1.6em 100%,
  1.4em 100%,
  1em 100%,
  0.8em 100%;

To maximize it more, I'ma use prime numbers. This trick could also help when it comes to animation (I mean prime numbers). 

background:  
  linear-gradient(90deg, black 19%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, red 41%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, #EAEAEA 61%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, red 83%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(90deg, black 97%, transparent 0);
  background-size: 19px 100%;
background-size:  
  19px 100%,
  13px 100%,
  17px 100%,
  7px 100%,
  10px 100%;

Cool, now I can safely go to my favorite colors, As a said before I used these colors just to make it easy for you to follow :)

And you can also change deg of each layer
for example, the first layer is 90deg, the second could be 45deg and so on ...

This is the final result

You can choose extreme light colors to make it blend very well with the white body background.

4. Let's design a checkboard!

You might think it's easy to make a checkboard pattern in CSS. That's true, but it's quite trickier than one might expect.

I'ma start with triangles

body {  
  background: 
    linear-gradient(45deg, black 25%, transparent 0);
  background-size: 1em 1em;
}

If we flip each color stop we can create triangles of the opposite direction and you know what will happen if we merge the two layers.

Hold on, Triangles! Why?

You may think creating two squares will solve the problem, but in CSS you can't create space around them and when the layer merge will happen, all you gonna see is a solid background.

Now, if we combine the two tringle layers, this is what we gonna see

background:  
    linear-gradient(45deg, black 25%, transparent 0),
    linear-gradient(45deg, transparent 75%, black 0);

In order to combine them into a square, we need to nudge the second layer by half the tile size

background:  
  linear-gradient(45deg, black 25%, transparent 0),
  linear-gradient(45deg, transparent 75%, black 0);
background-size: 1em 1em;  
background-position: 0 0, 0.5em 0.5em;

I'm going to double all layers and nudge them, then change the colors

body {  
  background-color: #E7E8E8;
  background-image: 
    linear-gradient(45deg, #D0D2D1 25%, transparent 0),
    linear-gradient(45deg, transparent 75%, #B9BBBB 0),
    linear-gradient(45deg, #8B8E8E 25%, transparent 0),
    linear-gradient(45deg, transparent 75%, #A2A5A4 0);
  background-size: 4em 4em;
  background-position:
    0 0,
    2em 2em,
    2em 2em,
    4em 4em;
}

And finally :)

5. What's next?

I'm hard working on creating new training video series to drastically help you become a stunning web developer.

Donate to help make these training courses FREE. Learning canâ€™t wait. Paypal.me/Zpyro

Zpyro Youtube Channel is here, Subscribe to get notified when I launch these courses.

item.title: Position any background image with offsets in all corners
item.description: How would you position a background image, `0.4em` from the right border and `1em` from the bottom border. Can you make it totally responsive ?
item.dc:creator: NedalKouissi
item.content:encoded:
You can read and watch previous episodes here!

What's the problem?

It'll be an easy task if I told you to position a background image, 0.4em from the left border & 1em from the top border. Right ?
The word "OR NAH." is a background image.

but, what about 1em from the bottom border and 0.2em from the right border ?

Of course, you'll have an answer, I did too. Sadly it wasn't the best.

I used to calculate the width and the height of the box, then I use subtraction.
In our example 1em from the bottom means box height - 1em.

That's totally okay, but in responsive design this solution is useless.

My next solution was to insert this background image as an actual <img />, so I could play with the layout. It works all the time, but adding extra markup just to solve a CSS issue is a big no-no.

Often times, the design is much complex than our example and because of that, I always end up with a very mangled and ugly HTML code.
Also if I wanted in the future to change the style, I'll need to go back and read the markup and ask myself why I did certain things in a certain way.

In CSS3, we're able to solve this problem so easily. First, we'll learn how then we'll practice by creating this album cover.

1. flexible background positioning

To control the position of any background image, we use the property background-position.

These 3 syntax below are quite popular, but they are not capable of accepting an offset.

background-position: bottom left;  
background-position: 10% 20%;  
background-position: 1em 2em;

The first value is for the x-axis and the second is for the y-axis.

The initial value of background-position is 0%.

background-position: 0% 0%;

1.1 background-position can accept offsets

We can express 1em from the bottom border and 0.2em from the left border as

background-position: bottom 1em left 0.2em;

for some reasons this syntax is not mentioned at MDN. I don't know why!

now we can easily switch it back to any corner with the exact measurement we want, all we need to do is change the keyword left to right

background-position: bottom 1em right 0.2em;

1.2 calc function

If i said background-position: bottom right;, That means 100% bottom and 100% right and I could express it like this

background-position: 100% 100%;

What if I could subtract the value that I'm aiming for as an offset.
the function calc can do this for me.

background-position: calc(100% - 1em) calc(100% - 0.2em);

as a result, we'll have something like this

1.3 Background origin & Padding

Remember, last episode when we used background-clip, the concept is similar.

for example

background-position: top;

We know that each CSS element has for boxes

so what box do top refer to?

border box?

Nop, by default it refers to the padding box, using background-origin we can change it to content-box.

background-position: bottom right;  
background-origin: content-box;

now we can add padding, to achieve what we want.

box-sizing: border-box;  
padding: 0 0.2em 1em 0

as a result

As you see I've used border-box to make sure any extra padding will not increase or change the box size.

1.4 Who's better?

The first method is more readable, but let's say we don't know the offset and we can only calculate it via javascript at render time. 'calc' will suit better.

There's no who's best unless we're talking about performance and to be honest, I don't know who performs better.

2. Let's practice

Last month I released Nuclin

Nuclin is a soundtrack album, there's no need for me to be concerned about including the Explicit flag into my album cover.

But you know what, let's redesign the album cover and add the Explicit flag to it.

first download the cover from here, and let's start.

<div class="card">  
  <img src="" alt="Nuclin Album cover" />
  <div class="topLayer"></div>
</div>

The <img /> is our cover.
.topLayer will hold the Explicit flag.

Everything is wrapped inside .card,so adding more elements will be easier in the future.

in our CSS, I'm gonna start with this

.card {
  width: 40%;
}

img {  
  max-width: 100%;
}

let's quickly add a little bit of box-shadow to the img
Tweak the shadows to your taste, this is what I came up with

Back to .topLayer, as I said we'll put the explicit flag as a background-image in this div.

First, we need .topLayer to be in the same .card size.

.topLayer {
  background-color: blue;
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  right: 0;
}

I'm trying to stretch .topLayer to it nearest relative, then I'm painting the whole layer with blue.
Now before I check if the whole .card is covered with blue, I must specify who's the relative

.card {
  width: 40%;
  position: relative;
}

Here we go

You can remove the blue background and instead insert the Explicit flag.

background: url(http://bit.ly/2gc3vRn) no-repeat;  
background-position: calc(100% - 0.4em) calc(100% - 1em);

to make the bottom of our album cover blend well with the white background. I will add an extra layer on top of everything

<div class="shine"></div>  

.shine {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  right: 0;
}

By default, the relative is body and that's exactly what we want.

I'm going to make this layer white at the bottom and transparent at the top

.shine {
  background: linear-gradient(180deg, transparent, white);
}

That's our final result

You can make the blend less obvious by lowering the opacity of .shine

3. What's next?

See you next episode :)

item.title: How to add depth to your design using multiple borders
item.description: Using box-shadow, outlines, background-clip to create multiple borders. Creating multiple orders helps to add depth and realism to your design.
item.dc:creator: NedalKouissi
item.content:encoded:
You can read and watch previous episodes here!

Is there any use cases?

Back in the days, they were so many ugly hacks to achieve multiple borders, now in CSS3 you can create similar results in a neat and straightforward way, and it's a good trick you can add to your CSS arsenal.

Below as you see, I've used various borders, to add depth to the right card.

See the Pen NbjyjJ by IDSFN (@IDSFN) on CodePen.

Here is another use case example.
You can imagine how many <dev> elements we need to create this color palette, but with multiple borders one CSS line was enough. Plus it's responsive. Yep!

See the Pen ENmgpx by IDSFN (@IDSFN) on CodePen.

also, multiple borders shines when it comes to animation.

Part1. How to achieve multiple borders in CSS3

In the upcoming sections, we'll learn how to create more than one border using multiple techniques.

1.1 Multiple borders via box-shadow

There's a fourth parameter that box-shadow accept, it's called spread radius.
If we combined spread radius with zero radius and zero blur, like you see below

background-color: #c0392b;  
box-shadow: 0 0 0 1em #ecf0f1;

We get a solid border. Something like this

See the Pen MbmjMM by IDSFN (@IDSFN) on CodePen.

If we want to add another border, we need to stack another line to box-shadow with a comma separate.

box-shadow: 0 0 0 1em red,   /* border 1 */  
            0 0 0 2em blue,  /* border 2 */
            0 0 0 3em black, /* border 3 */
            0 0 0 4em pink;  /* border 4 */

In our previous example, border1 is our top layer, border2 is underneath border1, etc ...
All box-shadows are overlaid one on top of the other, always add the SUM of previous layer sizes + the desired new border size.

for example, if I wanted border3 to be 3em in size: this is how you should do the math :D

(border1 size + border2 size) + border3 desired size

that means

(1em + 2em) + 3em = 6em.

What about the top, right, bottom or left?

You won't need radius for that, vertical shadow or horizontal shadow is enough.
The example below, will make it clear.

box-shadow: 0 -1em 0 red,    /* top border */  
            1em 0 0 blue,    /* right border */
            0 1em 0 black,   /* bottom border */
            -1em 0 0 yellow; /* left border */

here you can see it live

See the Pen ZBKBoO by IDSFN (@IDSFN) on CodePen.

notes :

  • Use the keyword inset, if you wanna capture mouse events on these fake borders.
  • Shadows don't affect layout, not like borders. The box-sizing property won't count them unless you put them inside the box, by using inset.
1.2 Multiple borders via outline

Bad news first, outline can only produce one border, but if we combine outline & border we'll have a total of 2.

here's an example :

border: 1em solid black;   /* Border 1 */  
outline: 1em solid yellow; /* Border 2 */

The downside of using outline is sharp corners, sadly outlines do not follow rounding through border-radius.

1.3 Multiple borders via background clip

I dedicated a whole episode for background clip. I'll move fast, but if you have any difficulties you can read the previous episode here.

By controlling the painting area using background-clip, you can fake it to make it look like you have a border.

here's an example :

See the Pen bBWLbx by IDSFN (@IDSFN) on CodePen.

As you see, i implemented only right borders, and I've used a mix of box-shadow, border and background-clip.
The first white border was a result of using background-clip, to break it down. Here's how!

background-color: #f1c40f;  
background-clip: content-box;  
/*
  Setting background clip to content box will make
  Background-color only paint the content box,
  padding & border box will stay untouched
*/

padding-right: 1em; /* This is our fake border */  
border-right: 1em solid #e67e22; /* This is border2 */

As a result, you'll have something like this

See the Pen aBWEgv by IDSFN (@IDSFN) on CodePen.

Part2. Apply it in a real life example

There's no need to make things complicated, all you need to do is play with shades.

Something like this:

.card2 {
  box-shadow: 0.08em 0.03em 0 #C2C2C8, /*Strong color*/
              0.2em 0.1em 0 #EDEDF4,   /*less stronger*/
              0.3em 0.2em 0 #EEEEF5,   /*less less*/
              0.3em 0.3em 0 #F0F0F6;   /*less less less*/
  }

It's trial and error, the more borders you add, the more depth you'll have. It'll take a little bit of experiment, but you'll get there.
I only spent 5min. Results are below.

See the Pen NbjyjJ by IDSFN (@IDSFN) on CodePen.

What's next ?

See you in the next episode :D

item.title: How To create a translucent border or padding without background color
item.description: By specifying the painting area, we can create a translucent border or add padding to the background (padding without background color), and much more
item.dc:creator: NedalKouissi
item.content:encoded:
You can read and watch previous episodes here.

Part1. What's the problem ?

Applying a translucent dotted border to a solid background.

Above is a visual to understand the problem easily, click on results button to see what I'm talking about.

  • box1 (I applied dotted border)
  • box2 (I tried to make it translucent, but the background is underneath, Oh snap!)
  • box3 (Problem fixed, no *background vs border clash!)*
  • box4 (I added padding, see how padding didn't get painted)

I'll explain how I did it from box2 to box3 & box4, after that, we will apply our knowledge to create something interesting like you see below!

Sounds good ?

Part2. How to achieve a translucent border ?

let's start with a red box

then let's add a solid blue border

after that let's make it a bit translucent, to do that we must convert HEX to HSLA or RGBA, that way we can control the opacity.

#34495e is equal to rgba(52, 73, 94, 1)

now replace the old HEX value within your border parameters, and choose the suitable opacity, something like this

Now we need to fix that border vs background clach

By default the background-color paints

  • The Content Box
  • The Padding Box
  • & The Border Box

All at once, DAMN!

Below is the CSS Box Model, so you could see what I'm talking about.

Also, you can inspect using the developer tools what we've just designed, to see clearly the box model in action

All we need to do is to change that behavior, we can specify where the painting must stop by using background-clip.

Here's all the properties that background-clip can take
background-clip: border-box|padding-box|content-box|initial|inherit;

Okay, back to our code, let's add background-clip: padding-box;

Cool, but what if I added a little bit of padding to the box?
The box will grow and that extra space will be painted in red :D, if this is not what you desire, go ahead and change background-clip.

background-clip: content-box;

this is the end result

Now, let's create something cool and interesting. but this time I want you to code with me.

This is what we gonna create (don't forget to hover)

Remember all episodes are about practical learning.

Part3. Apply the knowledge.

let's start with a simple F letter

<h2>F</h2>

I'm kinda trying to create a social facebook button, so probably you should wrap F in <a> tag.

Next, I want to add a light blue background and color F with dark blue

as you see, F, ain't in the center, let's center it Horizontally and vertically.

Cool, I guess it's time to add a tiny hover effect to our button.
On hover the background and the letter will switch colors, also the mouse cursor will change to pointer
as you see below.

it'll be much better if we slow down the transition,
also adding ease-in-out will make it so smooth.

Nice, let's add border to the left and a little of bit of padding to separate the left border with the actual background.

border-left: 0.1em solid #3b5999;  
padding-left: 0.1em;

You'll notice that padding-left didn't actually create any separation. WHY ?
I guess you already know, but if you didn't follow part1, the background paints the whole CSS Box Model by default, including the padding box and the border box.

That's why you saw an increase in size but you didn't see any separation between the border and the background.
And as I said before to change this behavior we need to use background-clip.

After adding background-clip: content-box; that's what we have so far, as a result

Note. I changed padding-left to a higher value to make it obvious.

Inside h2:hover let's add this

padding-left: 0;  
transition: background 0.3s ease-in-out,  
            padding 0.2s linear;

setting padding to O and adding a bit of transition will make the button move toward the border in a slick motion.

but wait, where's the border ?

the border now is in the same background color, so let's give it a different color.

Â´border-left: 0.2em solid #ecf0f1;Â´

By far this is what we have

If you still remember the result I've introduced at the end of Part2 is different than what we accomplished right now.

Your task now is to complete it until you create something similar to this

Hint. The border must increase in size, so it'll look like we are moving to the right, also change the color to white, that way it'll appear like it disappears.

Please don't look at the code unless you try, so it'll get stuck to your brain.

Conclusion

See you in episode 3, soon I'll introduce exercises and projects :)

item.title: 2Questions to constantly ask while writing CSS! EP1
item.description: Writing DRY and maintainable, flexible CSS code.
item.dc:creator: NedalKouissi
item.content:encoded:
Writing DRY and maintainable, flexible code is a huge topic and squeezing it only in 1 post is quite hard.
For that reason, I'll teach you two questions you should ask yourself whenever you write any CSS code, so your code will be in a much better state.

Wait, Why should I care?

If you are working on a big project, you'll suffer. Easy things will start to get hard to tweak because all you have is a mangled, hard to manage code.
Writing code that looks GOOD and performs GOOD is what you should aim for all the time.
Let's focus today on "Don't Repeat Yourself" AKA DRY.

Q1: Is it scalable?

What if I change font-size: 18px; to font-size: 45px;
do you think other related effects like drop-shadow will scale ? Absouletely not!

Shortly we will introduce redundant code.

to fix it, switch from px to % or em or rem.

Yeah, I do that all the time, that's responsive design basics!

We usually sleep on effects, and we think it won't make that much difference.

Q2: Does it do only one particular thing?

Each function must do only one particular job without mutating the state.

Same idea of Functional programming, to keep it simple ignore mutate and replace function with class.

in reality, it's impossible to create 100% functional CSS for the whole project.
Just like code coverage, nobody can get it to a 100%.

This where we left our code previously

Less code via responsive design

The more responsive your design is, the few media queries you'll use.

Here are some points you should pay attention to

  • Always use %, ems, vw or vh

  • Aim for max-width when you want a fixed width for large resolution, so it'll adapt automatically to smaller resolutions.

  • Set any replaced elements such as img, object, video, iframe to max-width: 100%;.

  • Scale your images via object-fit or background-size: cover;.

  • Use FlexBox for your layout.

If you find yourself with so many media query rules, go back and re-examine your code.
